Articles.Content:
It's a broom(stick - for line 2)

Verb - Sweep/Swept.

Actually used in Curling, if one wants to call that a sport.

I bring chaos into order, but I may stop at a border. - Such as the trim between two flooring types.

Those with hideous faces find I take them places. - Witches ride broomsticks.

From a field or from plastic, at what I do I'm fantastic, - Can have natural or plastic bristles, good at sweeping up dust/debris

But those in sport don't need me for it. - Sweepers in curling brush the ice

To some I'm friend but to others I'm foe, - no idea

And you'll find me most places you go.

What Am I?

Edited November 3, 2015 by Randazzo
Randazzo nailed it. The original sport reference was that brooms aren't needed to sweep a series or podium, aside from curling or the fictional sport of quidditch.

It's not very poetic, but here you go:

I exist as one, but always in a pair.

My parts alone bear a different name,

and my title changes with my role.

Sometimes I am long, sometimes I am short,

And other times I am even on a pole.

I must be borne slowly wherever I may go,

and never be used in a game.
Scissors?
plastic

Scissors?

At least it was quick and painless.

You are correct.
On a walk through a forest I got something. I sat down on a bench to look for it. Then I turned around and took it home with me because I couldn't find it. What was it?
Your shadow?
Nope.
Your train of thought?
nu-uh
A stone in your shoe or something similar?

A stone in your shoe or something similar?
I'll accept that, nice one. The intended answer was a splinter, but the spirit is the same.

Yay!

But I do not know any riddles, so lets wave the three-day-clause and let someone else step up right away.
What has Rivers and Oceans without Water, Mountains and Canyons without Land, Towns without People, Forests without Trees, What Am I?
A globe?
A map?
Correct, A Map, I suppose It could have been a Globe but I was thinking of a map, Congratz!!!

Ack, I forgot to post a riddle.

A guard dog is tied to a ten-foot chain. A burglar tries to sneak past 15 feet from the dog, but the dog rushes forward and bites the burglar. How is that possible when it was tied to a ten-foot chain?
The dog was at, say, the easternmost extent of the chain and the burglar walked by 15 ft to the west of him?
Nope. I meant to put distances to rule that out, but forgot.
Is the other end of the chain not attached to anything?

Is the other end of the chain not attached to anything?
Bingo

Stealing someone else's riddle, but it's a bit poetic:

IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m faithful and steadfast through twist and through turn Ã¢â‚¬â€œ

Your friend in the dark without star or sun.

The Earth is my mother; for her I still yearn,

And point to the place where all times are one.

What am I?
The Moon?
